definitions.definition: to receive something

examples.text: I **got a call** from Dave this morning.
What *(= What presents)* did you get for your birthday?
He gets *(= earns)* about $40 000 a year.
This room gets very little sunshine.
I got a shock when I saw the bill.
I will report back when I **get a chance**.
I **get the impression** that he is bored with his job.
Where did you **get the idea** from?
It's the best way to **get a sense **of what's actually going on here.
She got great satisfaction from seeing his embarrassment.

definitions.definition: to obtain something

examples.text: He has just **got a** new **job**.
I'll **get the money** somehow.
She opened the door wider to get a better look.
Try to get some sleep.
You can also **get information** on careers in social work from their website.
I think someone's trying to **get** your **attention**.
She really knows how to **get results**.

definitions.definition: to buy something
definitions.sensetop: get somethingget something for somebodyget somebody/yourself something

examples.text: Where did you get that skirt?
Did you manage to get tickets for the concert?
**Can I get** a Coke?
Did you get a present for your mother?
Did you get your mother a present?
Why don't you get yourself a car?
$100 will get you the basic model.
You can get yourself the basic model for $100.

definitions.definition: to obtain or receive an amount of money by selling something

examples.text: If you sell it at auction you can expect to get roughly £800.
How much did you get for your car?
We got £420 000 for the house.

definitions.definition: to go to a place and bring somebody/something back
definitions.sensetop: get somebody/somethingget something for somebodyget somebody/yourself something

examples.text: Quick—**go and get** a cloth!
Somebody get a doctor!
She went to **get help**.
I have to go and get my mother from the airport *(= collect her)*.
Get a drink for John.
Get John a drink.
She's gone to get a few more chairs.
Could you go upstairs and get my wallet for me, please?
Can I get you anything to eat or drink?

definitions.definition: to achieve or be given a particular mark or grade in an exam

examples.text: He got a ‘C’ in Chemistry and a ‘B’ in English.

definitions.definition: to start to develop an illness; to suffer from a pain, etc.

examples.text: I got this cold off *(= from)* you!
She gets *(= often suffers from)* really bad headaches.
I think I'm getting a cold.

definitions.definition: to receive something as a punishment

examples.text: He got ten years *(= was sent to prison for ten years)* for armed robbery.

definitions.definition: to connect to the internet or a phone network; to receive broadcasts from a particular television or radio station

examples.text: 95 per cent of the UK can now get superfast broadband.
I couldn't get any mobile phone reception.
We can't get Channel 5 in our area.

definitions.definition: to be connected with somebody by phone

examples.text: I wanted to speak to the manager but I got her assistant instead.

definitions.definition: to arrive at or reach a place or point

examples.text: We got to San Diego at 7 o'clock.
We're aiming to get to the party at about nine.
You got in very late last night.
I got back an hour ago.
Wait till we get home.
What time did you get here?
Let me know when you **get there**.
I haven't got very far with the book I'm reading.

definitions.definition: to move to or from a particular place or in a particular direction, sometimes with difficulty; to make somebody/something do this

examples.text: The bridge was destroyed so we couldn't get across the river.
She got into bed.
He got down from the ladder.
We didn't **get** *(= go)* **to bed** until 3 a.m.
Where do we **get on** the bus?
I'm **getting off** *(= leaving the train)* at the next station.
Where have they **got to** *(= where are they)*?
We must be getting home; it's past midnight.
We couldn't get the piano through the door.
We'd better call a taxi and get you home.
The general had to get his troops across the river.
I can't get the lid off.
How can we get to the other side of town?
I don't know how he managed to get down from the roof.
It takes an hour to get from Oxford to London.
We only got as far as the next town.
You can get to the hotel by bus or taxi.

definitions.definition: to use a bus, taxi, plane, etc.

examples.text: We're going to be late—let's get a taxi.
I usually get the bus to work.
Get a train to Newport and then get a bus from the station.
He got the next plane home.
I ran all the way to the station and just managed to get my train.
I'll try and get a flight home tomorrow.
You won't be able to get a plane there—there's no airport.

definitions.definition: to reach a particular state or condition; to make somebody/something/yourself reach a particular state or condition

examples.text: to get angry/bored/hungry/fat
to **get better/worse**
You'll soon **get used to** the climate here.
We ought to go; it's getting late.
to **get dressed/undressed** *(= to put your clothes on/take your clothes off)*
They plan to **get married** in the summer.
She's upstairs **getting ready**.
As he's **got older** his tastes have changed.
She was **getting sick** of hearing him complain.
There's nothing to **get excited** about.
He **got drunk** and passed out.
I was starting to **get tired**.
I wouldn't go there alone; you might get *(= be)* mugged.
My car got *(= was)* stolen at the weekend.
Don't get your dress dirty!
He got his fingers caught in the door.
I'm trying to get the children ready for school.

definitions.definition: to reach the point at which you feel, know, are, etc. something

examples.text: After a time you get to realize that these things don't matter.
You'll like her once you **get to know** her.
His drinking is getting to be a problem.
She's getting to be an old lady now.

definitions.definition: to cause something to happen or be done

examples.text: I must get my hair cut.
I'll never get all this work finished.
She has a reputation for **getting things done**.

definitions.definition: to make, persuade, etc. somebody/something to do something
definitions.sensetop: get somebody/something to do somethingget somebody/something doing something

examples.text: I couldn't get the car to start this morning.
He got his sister to help him with his homework.
You'll never get him to understand.
It's not hard to get him talking—the problem is stopping him!
Can you really get that old car going again?
I finally got Michael to talk to them and he explained everything.
We had trouble getting enough people to sign up.

definitions.definition: to start doing something

examples.text: I got talking to her.
We need to **get going** soon.

definitions.definition: to have the opportunity to do something

examples.text: He got to try out all the new software.
It's not fair—I never get to go first.

definitions.definition: to prepare a meal
definitions.sensetop: get somethingget something for somebody/yourselfget somebody/yourself something

examples.text: Who's getting the lunch?
You sit down and relax. I'll get supper.
I must go home and get tea for the kids.
I must go home and get the kids their tea.

definitions.definition: to answer the phone or a door when somebody calls, knocks, etc.

examples.text: Will you get the door?

definitions.definition: to catch or take hold of somebody, especially in order to harm or punish them

examples.text: He was on the run for a week before the police got him.
to get somebody by the arm/wrist/throat
She fell overboard and the sharks got her.
He thinks everybody is **out to get him** *(= trying to harm him)*.
**I'll get you** for that!

definitions.definition: to hit or wound somebody

examples.text: The bullet got him in the neck.

definitions.definition: to understand somebody/something

examples.text: I don't get you.
She didn't get the joke.
I **don't get it**—why would she do a thing like that?
I **get the message**—you don't want me to come.

definitions.definition: used to say that something happens or exists

examples.text: **You get** *(= There are)* all these kids hanging around in the street.
They still get cases of typhoid there.

definitions.definition: to make somebody feel confused because they do not understand something

examples.text: ‘What's the capital of Bhutan?’ ‘**You've got me there!**’ *(= I don't know)*

definitions.definition: to annoy somebody

examples.text: **What gets me** is having to do the same thing all day long.

definitions.definition: to be becoming old
to be becoming late

examples.text: The time's getting on—we ought to be going.

definitions.definition: to be nearly a particular time, age or number

examples.text: It must be getting on for midnight.
He's getting on for eighty.

definitions.definition: used to say that you are shocked, surprised, etc. by something

examples.text: I can't get over how rude she was.

definitions.definition: to have a short holiday in a place where you can relax
to leave a place in order to go somewhere else

examples.text: It's been lovely to see you, but it's probably time we got going.

definitions.definition: to start happening or being done

examples.text: The project hasn't really got going yet.

definitions.definition: to make somebody angry, worried or excited
to succeed in starting a machine, vehicle, process, etc.

examples.text: We finally managed to get the car going.

definitions.definition: to be punished or spoken to angrily about something

examples.text: If your dad finds out you'll really get it!

definitions.definition: to have sex with somebody
to have an erection
to not help somebody make progress or succeed

examples.text: This line of investigation is getting us nowhere.
Being rude to me won't get you anywhere.

definitions.definition: to make some progress/no progress

examples.text: After six months' work on the project, at last I feel I'm getting somewhere.
I don't seem to be getting anywhere with this essay.

definitions.definition: to achieve your aim or complete a task

examples.text: I'm sure you'll get there in the end.
It's not perfect but **we're getting there** *(= making progress)*.

definitions.definition: used to say that you are going to tell somebody something that they will find surprising or interesting

examples.text: OK, get this guys—there are only two left!
So get this—I did all the work and he got the money.

definitions.definition: used to express surprise or disapproval that somebody has been so selfish, stupid, etc.
you have to admit that something unpleasant is true
used to ask, especially in an angry way, what somebody is/was suggesting

examples.text: I'm partly to blame? What exactly are you getting at?

definitions.definition: used to say that somebody has suddenly started to behave in a strange or different way

examples.text: What's got into Alex? He never used to worry like that.
I’m sorry for laughing like that—I don’t know what got into me.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old Norse geta ‘obtain, beget, guess’; related to Old English gietan (in begietan ‘beget’, forgietan ‘forget’), from an Indo-European root shared by Latin praeda ‘booty, prey’, praehendere ‘get hold of, seize’, and Greek khandanein ‘hold, contain, be able’.
